content: A Legacy of Gendered Self-Doubt How do we overcome a culture that demands women be humble to a fault? Stephanie Sylverne Blocked Unblock Follow Following Feb 17 Grandma and me. Photo: Stephanie Sylverne T wo years ago, while my grandmother was dying of cancer, I discovered she’d once had a calligraphy piece in an exhibition at the Newberry Library, an independent research institution in Chicago. She didn’t tell me this herself; I happened to find an old brochure from the event with her name listed as an exhibitor. How could she neglect to mention this? Being part of a Newberry exhibition is a bragworthy accomplishment. Plus, I’d started working on a historical novel that featured the library rather prominently, and was also based quite a bit on her family’s past, so the connection was sort of serendipitous. I asked her where the piece was. I wanted to add it to the shrine of her artwork I’d been steadily collecting at home. “Oh, that. I gave that away a long time ago,” she told me. “You gave it away? Why?” “Someone offered to buy it. Lots of people had prices on theirs. But I was too embarrassed to charge anything for mine. So I said, ‘If you like it, you can just have it.’ I always gave them away if anyone asked.” Later, she told me she was once asked to be a calligrapher for someone’s wedding. It involved writing hundreds of invitations, the kind of offer any artist would be thrilled to receive. Everyone who knew her work agreed that she possessed a remarkable talent. Unfortunately, her self-doubt was just as vast as her potential. “I didn’t want to do it because I’d be embarrassed if it wasn’t good enough,” she said. “So when the woman asked me how much I’d charge, I gave her a really high quote. That way, I figured she’d have to say no. But she said, ‘Okay.’ I was shocked! Then I thought, ‘Oh shoot, I guess I really have to do it now. What if it’s terrible? She’ll ask for her money back.’” Of course, that didn’t happen. The woman called to thank her profusely, raving about the beauty of the invitations. She did turn down other offers, though. If she hadn’t, she likely could have had a career as a freelance calligrapher or instructor. After all, this wasn’t merely a casual hobby—she spent unbelievable amounts of time and money taking courses at Columbia College and elsewhere. She gained acceptance to private classes with well-known calligraphy masters, and she was a member of the Chicago Calligraphy Collective, a nonprofit network and artist community. Everyone who knew her work agreed that she possessed a remarkable talent. Unfortunately, her self-doubt was just as vast as her potential. Instead of pursuing her calling, my incredibly gifted grandmother worked full-time in a tool factory for 40 years. I keep a notebook on the shelf above my desk. It’s called The Art of Writing, An Illustrated Journal. It’s sprinkled with inspirational quotes on blank pages meant to be filled with words. Inside the front cover are the words “From Grandma, October 1995.” I was 16. I remember being flattered that she gave me something so grown-up, so serious, especially next to my spiral notebooks covered in band stickers and doodled graffiti. At the time, I hadn’t written much of anything. Certainly nothing of substance. My literary output back then amounted to a lot of angsty teenage screeds in insufficiently locked diaries and hideous poems about jilted love, fueled by hormonal rage. It’s true that I’d loved books since before I could even read them, so I’d always had the vague idea that someday I’d like to see my name on the cover of one, but she seemed to think I was secretly stashing the Great American Novel in my dresser drawer. Such high expectations were a compliment but also a lot of pressure. “I don’t even know what to write about,” I’d tell her. “Write about me,” she’d say. Her support was typical proud grandma fare, but it was also, I think, an attempt to fix what was broken in herself. Her unrealized dreams could be soothed by seeing something like them manifest in her granddaughter. She didn’t just encourage me to push forward, she demanded that I do. Begin. Falter. Quit. Repeat. It’s apparently what we do—it’s what many women do. In fact, one of the last things my grandma ever said to me, between raspy, measured breaths, was, “Is your book done yet?” Three years, hundreds of pages, and countless hours later, not to mention dollars—in tuition for a master’s degree; to pay a babysitter while I wrote; doled out for any and every book related, however tangentially, to my historical subject; even to fund a research trip to D.C.—no, it’s not done yet. The manuscript sits in bits and pieces, unfinished. It’s not good enough. I’d fully intended to finish it in time for my grandma to see it—if not published, then at least whole—so I could print it out for her to read. It was, in a way, her dying wish. Every time I visited her home or her hospital bed, she’d ask the same question, “Is your book done yet?” But I could never get over the embarrassment of actually handing it over, the thought of her reading what I wrote and secretly thinking, “this sucks,” though I knew she would never say anything like that out loud. Did I really want my grandmother to leave this world with my subpar manuscript on her mind? My deepest, most horrible fear was that she would go realizing she’d been wrong about me all along. So I abandoned the book. I started other projects, increasingly aware of a repeated pattern. Like my grandmother, my mother is creative and artistically inclined. She also suffers from a crushing case of Not Good Enough. Despite the fact that the elaborate costumes she’s made my daughters have received generous compliments, despite requests from other parents who want to commission their own, my mother always says the stitches aren’t straight enough, the fabric isn’t falling quite as she’d envisioned, the sewing machine isn’t cooperating. “You could start an Etsy shop and sell these,” I tell her. “Are you kidding?” she says. “I’d be embarrassed.” More often than not, she abandons her sewing projects before they’re completed. Begin. Falter. Quit. Repeat. It’s apparently what we do—me, my mom, and my grandma. It’s what many women do. A friend posted a Sylvia Plath quote online: “The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt.” Numerous studies have suggested that this—crushing self-doubt—is primarily a women’s ailment, one Plath herself infamously suffered from . This is not to say all women have this problem or that we all experience it in the same way. But when I look around, I see it everywhere: in my family, my friends, even strangers on the internet. Yes, men experience self-doubt, too, but women are socially conditioned for it. Male self-doubt is personal, individual. It’s not the result of a culture that demands they be humble to a fault. Be nice, women are told. Be likable. It’s neither nice nor likable to think too highly of yourself. It’s not nice or likable to compete or boast—those things must done surreptitiously, if at all. I don’t think of myself as a people pleaser. I’m opinionated. I’m rebellious. But have those messages of likability affected me anyway? Are they already planted in my head, waiting for just the right moment to explode? I thought about the names of the other Newberry exhibitors in my grandma’s brochure, the ones whose pieces said “SOLD” next to them. Names like Bob, Richard, John. I thought about the names of her instructors. I thought about the names on the personal business cards she had in her calligraphy room, the saved correspondence with her instructors and peers: “Dear Joan, Keep up the good work. — Bill.” Would my grandmother’s male colleagues turn down a job offer for fear they didn’t deserve it? Would they toil away for endless hours, months, years, and hide the results of their hard work, thinking it was never good enough? In a 2014 article for the Guardian, Jessica Valenti wrote: It’s true that there’s a gendered disparity in confidence—American men overestimate their abilities and skills while women underestimate them. In fact, we’ve known this for some time: ‘imposter syndrome’—a phenomenon in which high-achieving women believe ‘they are really not bright and have fooled anyone who thinks otherwise’—was first written about in 1978. In the Atlantic , Katty Kay and Claire Shipman covered “ The Confidence Gap ” between men and women and “How Puberty Kills Girls’ Confidence .” A cursory Google search reveals similar coverage in the New York Times , Huffington Post , and Forbes . These stories mention a nationwide survey conducted by Ypulse, which found that “at age 14, girls experience their lowest levels of self-assurance, 27 percent lower than boys report at the same age” and that “girls are more likely than boys to describe themselves as stressed, anxious, shy, emotional, worried, depressed, and ugly while boys are more likely to say they’re confident, strong, adventurous, and fearless.” That divide never fully closes. In response, there is an entire genre of books about this phenomenon aimed at women. Sheryl Sandberg’s Lean In may be the most zeitgeisty, but there’s also Nice Girls Don’t Get the Corner Office by Lois Frankel and Grit by Angela Duckworth. These books tend to focus on the behavior of women as individuals, suggesting personal failings we must overcome. Evidently, we—me, my mother, my grandmother—are not alone. I grew up watching my mother abandon projects. I saw my grandmother toil away all day for little pay while she sidelined her true passion. I won’t be like that, I swore. I entered adulthood obsessed with proving I could finish whatever I started. But eventually, when things got too real, the doubt caught up with me. This work isn’t good enough. I’m not good enough. My grandmother is gone but I still hear her in my sleep, asking, “Is your book done yet?” Recently, I opened the dog-eared book of quotations I took from her calligraphy room and read: “Our doubts are traitors And make us lose the good we oft might win By fearing to attempt.” I remember my great-grandmother, holding her thin hand over mine at the kitchen table and smiling. I wonder what her unrealized talent was. What potential did she suppress, only to have it seep out of her, permeating her home for my grandmother and her sisters to absorb? How far back does it go? How many women in my family, in all of ours, have sat silently, wishing for fulfillment but doubting they could have it, that they deserved it, while the men around them kept making mistakes and moving past them toward success? The next time my grandma comes to me in a dream and asks, “Yet?” I’ll say yes. This essay was originally published in the Feminist issue of Chicago Literati , April 2015.
title_html: A Legacy of Gendered Self-Doubt
html:

11:27

A Legacy of Gendered Self-Doubt

How do we overcome a culture that demands women be humble to a fault?

Stephanie Sylverne
Feb 17

Two years ago, while my grandmother was dying of cancer, I discovered she’d once had a calligraphy piece in an exhibition at the Newberry Library, an independent research institution in Chicago. She didn’t tell me this herself; I happened to find an old brochure from the event with her name listed as an exhibitor.

How could she neglect to mention this? Being part of a Newberry exhibition is a bragworthy accomplishment. Plus, I’d started working on a historical novel that featured the library rather prominently, and was also based quite a bit on her family’s past, so the connection was sort of serendipitous.

I asked her where the piece was. I wanted to add it to the shrine of her artwork I’d been steadily collecting at home.

“Oh, that. I gave that away a long time ago,” she told me.

“You gave it away? Why?”

“Someone offered to buy it. Lots of people had prices on theirs. But I was too embarrassed to charge anything for mine. So I said, ‘If you like it, you can just have it.’ I always gave them away if anyone asked.”

Later, she told me she was once asked to be a calligrapher for someone’s wedding. It involved writing hundreds of invitations, the kind of offer any artist would be thrilled to receive.

Everyone who knew her work agreed that she possessed a remarkable talent. Unfortunately, her self-doubt was just as vast as her potential.

“I didn’t want to do it because I’d be embarrassed if it wasn’t good enough,” she said. “So when the woman asked me how much I’d charge, I gave her a really high quote. That way, I figured she’d have to say no. But she said, ‘Okay.’ I was shocked! Then I thought, ‘Oh shoot, I guess I really have to do it now. What if it’s terrible? She’ll ask for her money back.’”

Of course, that didn’t happen. The woman called to thank her profusely, raving about the beauty of the invitations.

She did turn down other offers, though. If she hadn’t, she likely could have had a career as a freelance calligrapher or instructor. After all, this wasn’t merely a casual hobby—she spent unbelievable amounts of time and money taking courses at Columbia College and elsewhere. She gained acceptance to private classes with well-known calligraphy masters, and she was a member of the Chicago Calligraphy Collective, a nonprofit network and artist community.

Everyone who knew her work agreed that she possessed a remarkable talent. Unfortunately, her self-doubt was just as vast as her potential. Instead of pursuing her calling, my incredibly gifted grandmother worked full-time in a tool factory for 40 years.

I keep a notebook on the shelf above my desk. It’s called The Art of Writing, An Illustrated Journal. It’s sprinkled with inspirational quotes on blank pages meant to be filled with words. Inside the front cover are the words “From Grandma, October 1995.”

I was 16. I remember being flattered that she gave me something so grown-up, so serious, especially next to my spiral notebooks covered in band stickers and doodled graffiti. At the time, I hadn’t written much of anything. Certainly nothing of substance. My literary output back then amounted to a lot of angsty teenage screeds in insufficiently locked diaries and hideous poems about jilted love, fueled by hormonal rage. It’s true that I’d loved books since before I could even read them, so I’d always had the vague idea that someday I’d like to see my name on the cover of one, but she seemed to think I was secretly stashing the Great American Novel in my dresser drawer. Such high expectations were a compliment but also a lot of pressure. “I don’t even know what to write about,” I’d tell her.

“Write about me,” she’d say.

Her support was typical proud grandma fare, but it was also, I think, an attempt to fix what was broken in herself. Her unrealized dreams could be soothed by seeing something like them manifest in her granddaughter. She didn’t just encourage me to push forward, she demanded that I do.

Begin. Falter. Quit. Repeat. It’s apparently what we do—it’s what many women do.

In fact, one of the last things my grandma ever said to me, between raspy, measured breaths, was, “Is your book done yet?”

Three years, hundreds of pages, and countless hours later, not to mention dollars—in tuition for a master’s degree; to pay a babysitter while I wrote; doled out for any and every book related, however tangentially, to my historical subject; even to fund a research trip to D.C.—no, it’s not done yet. The manuscript sits in bits and pieces, unfinished.

It’s not good enough.

I’d fully intended to finish it in time for my grandma to see it—if not published, then at least whole—so I could print it out for her to read. It was, in a way, her dying wish. Every time I visited her home or her hospital bed, she’d ask the same question, “Is your book done yet?” But I could never get over the embarrassment of actually handing it over, the thought of her reading what I wrote and secretly thinking, “this sucks,” though I knew she would never say anything like that out loud. Did I really want my grandmother to leave this world with my subpar manuscript on her mind? My deepest, most horrible fear was that she would go realizing she’d been wrong about me all along.

So I abandoned the book. I started other projects, increasingly aware of a repeated pattern.

Like my grandmother, my mother is creative and artistically inclined. She also suffers from a crushing case of Not Good Enough. Despite the fact that the elaborate costumes she’s made my daughters have received generous compliments, despite requests from other parents who want to commission their own, my mother always says the stitches aren’t straight enough, the fabric isn’t falling quite as she’d envisioned, the sewing machine isn’t cooperating.

“You could start an Etsy shop and sell these,” I tell her.

“Are you kidding?” she says. “I’d be embarrassed.”

More often than not, she abandons her sewing projects before they’re completed. Begin. Falter. Quit. Repeat. It’s apparently what we do—me, my mom, and my grandma. It’s what many women do.

A friend posted a Sylvia Plath quote online: “The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt.” Numerous studies have suggested that this—crushing self-doubt—is primarily a women’s ailment, one Plath herself infamously suffered from. This is not to say all women have this problem or that we all experience it in the same way. But when I look around, I see it everywhere: in my family, my friends, even strangers on the internet. Yes, men experience self-doubt, too, but women are socially conditioned for it. Male self-doubt is personal, individual. It’s not the result of a culture that demands they be humble to a fault.

Be nice, women are told. Be likable. It’s neither nice nor likable to think too highly of yourself. It’s not nice or likable to compete or boast—those things must done surreptitiously, if at all. I don’t think of myself as a people pleaser. I’m opinionated. I’m rebellious. But have those messages of likability affected me anyway? Are they already planted in my head, waiting for just the right moment to explode?

I thought about the names of the other Newberry exhibitors in my grandma’s brochure, the ones whose pieces said “SOLD” next to them. Names like Bob, Richard, John. I thought about the names of her instructors. I thought about the names on the personal business cards she had in her calligraphy room, the saved correspondence with her instructors and peers: “Dear Joan, Keep up the good work. — Bill.” Would my grandmother’s male colleagues turn down a job offer for fear they didn’t deserve it? Would they toil away for endless hours, months, years, and hide the results of their hard work, thinking it was never good enough?

In a 2014 article for the Guardian, Jessica Valenti wrote:

It’s true that there’s a gendered disparity in confidence—American men overestimate their abilities and skills while women underestimate them. In fact, we’ve known this for some time: ‘imposter syndrome’—a phenomenon in which high-achieving women believe ‘they are really not bright and have fooled anyone who thinks otherwise’—was first written about in 1978.

In the Atlantic, Katty Kay and Claire Shipman covered “The Confidence Gap” between men and women and “How Puberty Kills Girls’ Confidence.” A cursory Google search reveals similar coverage in the New York Times, Huffington Post, and Forbes. These stories mention a nationwide survey conducted by Ypulse, which found that “at age 14, girls experience their lowest levels of self-assurance, 27 percent lower than boys report at the same age” and that “girls are more likely than boys to describe themselves as stressed, anxious, shy, emotional, worried, depressed, and ugly while boys are more likely to say they’re confident, strong, adventurous, and fearless.” That divide never fully closes.

In response, there is an entire genre of books about this phenomenon aimed at women. Sheryl Sandberg’s Lean In may be the most zeitgeisty, but there’s also Nice Girls Don’t Get the Corner Office by Lois Frankel and Grit by Angela Duckworth. These books tend to focus on the behavior of women as individuals, suggesting personal failings we must overcome. Evidently, we—me, my mother, my grandmother—are not alone.

I grew up watching my mother abandon projects. I saw my grandmother toil away all day for little pay while she sidelined her true passion. I won’t be like that, I swore. I entered adulthood obsessed with proving I could finish whatever I started. But eventually, when things got too real, the doubt caught up with me. This work isn’t good enough. I’m not good enough.

My grandmother is gone but I still hear her in my sleep, asking, “Is your book done yet?”

Recently, I opened the dog-eared book of quotations I took from her calligraphy room and read:

“Our doubts are traitors

And make us lose the good we oft might win

By fearing to attempt.”

I remember my great-grandmother, holding her thin hand over mine at the kitchen table and smiling. I wonder what her unrealized talent was. What potential did she suppress, only to have it seep out of her, permeating her home for my grandmother and her sisters to absorb? How far back does it go? How many women in my family, in all of ours, have sat silently, wishing for fulfillment but doubting they could have it, that they deserved it, while the men around them kept making mistakes and moving past them toward success?

The next time my grandma comes to me in a dream and asks, “Yet?”

I’ll say yes.

This essay was originally published in the Feminist issue of Chicago Literati, April 2015.

    Writer and aspiring time traveler. Essays at Mental Floss, Time, Kveller, Huffington Post, etc.

title: A Legacy of Gendered Self-Doubt
content_html:
A Legacy of Gendered Self-Doubt

How do we overcome a culture that demands women be humble to a fault?

Stephanie Sylverne
Feb 17

Two years ago, while my grandmother was dying of cancer, I discovered she’d once had a calligraphy piece in an exhibition at the Newberry Library, an independent research institution in Chicago. She didn’t tell me this herself; I happened to find an old brochure from the event with her name listed as an exhibitor.

How could she neglect to mention this? Being part of a Newberry exhibition is a bragworthy accomplishment. Plus, I’d started working on a historical novel that featured the library rather prominently, and was also based quite a bit on her family’s past, so the connection was sort of serendipitous.

I asked her where the piece was. I wanted to add it to the shrine of her artwork I’d been steadily collecting at home.

“Oh, that. I gave that away a long time ago,” she told me.

Later, she told me she was once asked to be a calligrapher for someone’s wedding. It involved writing hundreds of invitations, the kind of offer any artist would be thrilled to receive.

“I didn’t want to do it because I’d be embarrassed if it wasn’t good enough,” she said. “So when the woman asked me how much I’d charge, I gave her a really high quote. That way, I figured she’d have to say no. But she said, ‘Okay.’ I was shocked! Then I thought, ‘Oh shoot, I guess I really have to do it now. What if it’s terrible? She’ll ask for her money back.’”

Of course, that didn’t happen. The woman called to thank her profusely, raving about the beauty of the invitations.

She did turn down other offers, though. If she hadn’t, she likely could have had a career as a freelance calligrapher or instructor. She gained acceptance to private classes with well-known calligraphy masters, and she was a member of the Chicago Calligraphy Collective, a nonprofit network and artist community.

In fact, one of the last things my grandma ever said to me, between raspy, measured breaths, was, “Is your book done yet?”

Three years, hundreds of pages, and countless hours later, not to mention dollars—in tuition for a master’s degree; to pay a babysitter while I wrote; doled out for any and every book related, however tangentially, to my historical subject; even to fund a research trip to D.C.—no, it’s not done yet. The manuscript sits in bits and pieces, unfinished.

It’s not good enough.

I’d fully intended to finish it in time for my grandma to see it—if not published, then at least whole—so I could print it out for her to read. It was, in a way, her dying wish. Every time I visited her home or her hospital bed, she’d ask the same question, “Is your book done yet?” But I could never get over the embarrassment of actually handing it over, the thought of her reading what I wrote and secretly thinking, “this sucks,” though I knew she would never say anything like that out loud. Did I really want my grandmother to leave this world with my subpar manuscript on her mind? My deepest, most horrible fear was that she would go realizing she’d been wrong about me all along.

So I abandoned the book. I started other projects, increasingly aware of a repeated pattern.

Like my grandmother, my mother is creative and artistically inclined. She also suffers from a crushing case of Not Good Enough. Despite the fact that the elaborate costumes she’s made my daughters have received generous compliments, despite requests from other parents who want to commission their own, my mother always says the stitches aren’t straight enough, the fabric isn’t falling quite as she’d envisioned, the sewing machine isn’t cooperating.

“You could start an Etsy shop and sell these,” I tell her.

“Are you kidding?” she says. “I’d be embarrassed.”

More often than not, she abandons her sewing projects before they’re completed. Begin. Falter. Quit. Repeat. It’s apparently what we do—me, my mom, and my grandma. It’s what many women do.

A friend posted a Sylvia Plath quote online: “The worst enemy to creativity is self-doubt.” Numerous studies have suggested that this—crushing self-doubt—is primarily a women’s ailment, one Plath herself infamously suffered from. I thought about the names of the other Newberry exhibitors in my grandma’s brochure, the ones whose pieces said “SOLD” next to them. Names like Bob, Richard, John. In the Atlantic, Katty Kay and Claire Shipman covered “The Confidence Gap” between men and women and “How Puberty Kills Girls’ Confidence.” A cursory Google search reveals similar coverage in the New York Times, Huffington Post, and Forbes. These stories mention a nationwide survey conducted by Ypulse, which found that “at age 14, girls experience their lowest levels of self-assurance, 27 percent lower than boys report at the same age” and that “girls are more likely than boys to describe themselves as stressed, anxious, shy, emotional, worried, depressed, and ugly while boys are more likely to say they’re confident, strong, adventurous, and fearless.” That divide never fully closes.

In response, there is an entire genre of books about this phenomenon aimed at women. Sheryl Sandberg’s Lean In may be the most zeitgeisty, but there’s also Nice Girls Don’t Get the Corner Office by Lois Frankel and Grit by Angela Duckworth. These books tend to focus on the behavior of women as individuals, suggesting personal failings we must overcome. Evidently, we—me, my mother, my grandmother—are not alone.

I grew up watching my mother abandon projects. I saw my grandmother toil away all day for little pay while she sidelined her true passion. I won’t be like that, I swore. I entered adulthood obsessed with proving I could finish whatever I started. But eventually, when things got too real, the doubt caught up with me. This work isn’t good enough. I’m not good enough.

My grandmother is gone but I still hear her in my sleep, asking, “Is your book done yet?”

Recently, I opened the dog-eared book of quotations I took from her calligraphy room and read:

“Our doubts are traitors

And make us lose the good we oft might win

By fearing to attempt.”

I remember my great-grandmother, holding her thin hand over mine at the kitchen table and smiling. I wonder what her unrealized talent was. What potential did she suppress, only to have it seep out of her, permeating her home for my grandmother and her sisters to absorb? How far back does it go? How many women in my family, in all of ours, have sat silently, wishing for fulfillment but doubting they could have it, that they deserved it, while the men around them kept making mistakes and moving past them toward success?

The next time my grandma comes to me in a dream and asks, “Yet?”

I’ll say yes.

This essay was originally published in the Feminist issue of Chicago Literati, April 2015.
